But we also have

that e to the it is the

times the sine of t. So it's through Euler's

oscillations are coming in. The direct method led

But the next day, Euler

to the minus it-- or probably being Euler, it

So the conclusion is linear
constant coefficient

differential equations are
completely solved by trying e

to the lambda t and finding
that number lambda.

If it's a real number,
we have exponentials. If it's an imaginary number,
we have sines and cosines.

If it's a repeated number,
we have an extra factor t showing up.

That's the exceptional event
in that particular case.

So there you go. Differential equations
with constant coefficients we can handle.
